Award.AwardTitle: NSMDS: Sustainable chemical innovations by an integrated design approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Division of Chemistry and Environmental Protection Agency support Professors Brian B. Laird, Raghunath V. Chaudhari, Bala Subramaniam, Ward H. Thompson and Jon A. Tunge of the University of Kansas for a collaborative effort on Networks for Sustainable Molecular Design and Synthesis. One challenge facing the chemical industry is the development of sustainable manufacturing processes that eliminate the use of hazardous materials, minimize waste, conserve resources, and improve safety. In this project, Professor Laird and his team of chemists and chemical engineers use an integrated approach to address this challenge. This research effort uses molecular modeling, synthesis, reactor engineering, kinetic studies and life-cycle assessments to develop and optimize the design of industrial catalytic processes for minimal environmental impact. This framework is being applied to two examples of high-volume chemical processes. One is a safer, phosgene-free route to dimethyl carbonate, which is used to manufacture polycarbonates and polyurethanes. The other process is a cleaner, more efficient route from butadiene to adipic acid, a commodity chemical used to make nylon.

Phosgene, although a common industrial chemical, is toxic and detrimental to the environment. The development of green chemistry which bypasses toxic intermediates is an important goal. The discoveries and methodologies developed for the chemicals studied here find broader applications for other major chemical processes. In addition, the next generation of scientists and engineers are being trained to work in multidisciplinary teams and become skilled communicators. By translating project results into educational laboratory activities, which include high school students and/or college freshmen, a broad cross-section of the nascent workforce benefits.

Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project brought together expertise in computational chemistry, catalyst synthesis, and reaction engineering to create a new integrated design approach for new chemical catalysts. This paradigm revealed new ways to characterize and predict catalyst properties and behaviors that are not readily observable by traditional experimental methods alone. These discoveries bring us closer to new processes for chemical manufacturing that are both safer and less-polluting than currently practiced methods.

One of the target processes is a safer, phosgene-free route to dimethyl carbonate, which is an important solvent used in multiple applications, including lithium ion batteries and polycarbonate plastics. The other process is a cleaner, more efficient route from butadiene to adipic acid, a commodity chemical used to make nylon.  

The mechanisms of these reactions were probed by simulation of the active catalyst sites, resulting in hypotheses that were tested on suitably modified/redesigned catalysts. Molecular simulations were also carried out to understand the behavior of the reaction mixtures inside the catalyst mesopores—which is extremely difficult to measure directly—versus the properties of the same fluids in the bulk. The performance of the improved catalysts and processes were benchmarked against metrics determined by economic and environmental assessments of commercial manufacturing processes.

The resulting novel catalysts developed in this program were also tested for other important applications, notably light olefin metathesis and hydroformylation of propene/propane mixtures—both of which can make use of abundant natural gas liquids as feedstocks.

The research advances in this project resulted in 34 technical publications, 42 conference presentations, 6 PhD dissertations, and 1 patent application. This grant provided 30 students and postdoctoral researchers a unique interdisciplinary training experience for careers as innovators and educators.

The outcomes of this project were also leveraged by an NSF Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) grant to provide high school teachers new learning materials. X-ray fluorescence instrumentation acquired under this project not only enabled this research program, but also led to new public science outreach activities in conjunction with the KU Natural History Museum. Moreover, the success of the integrated design approach demonstrated in this project has led to its adoption on a number of other research projects.


Last Modified: 01/29/2019
Modified by: Brian B Laird

The resulting novel catalysts developed in this program were also tested for other important applications, notably light olefin metathesis and hydroformylation of propene/propane mixtures—both of which can make use of abundant natural gas liquids as feedstocks.
